Award.AwardTitle: Environmental change and the ecological dynamics of Great Basin small mammals over the past century: Insights from historical museum records and modern resurveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses historical museum records and modern field surveys to assess changes in the small mammal communities of the Great Basin over the past century. Comparative "then and now" data from resurveyed historical localities, information from repeat photography, and historical and modern climate data will be used to distinguish the relative impact of human land use and climate change on Great Basin mammals. Preliminary data from the Ruby Mountains reveal major faunal changes over the past 80 years. At local sites, these include the apparent loss or gain of species or changes in species relative abundance. Some local changes are associated with altered plant communities and reflect land-use history, whereas others are likely direct responses to climate change. Local community similarity has decreased over time, and faunal changes have been most profound at lower elevations. Across elevation, distributions of some moisture-loving species have shifted upslope consistent with predicted response to climate change. In contrast, ranges of arid-adapted species have not expanded.

Land use, invasive species, and climate change have altered biotic communities throughout the Great Basin, now considered one of the most threatened bioregions in North America. Understanding how species and communities respond to environmental change requires a longterm perspective. This research will develop the use of museum data to investigate faunal response to environmental change. It will generate additional data for investigating future biotic change, and to support future studies on the ecology, population genetics, and biogeography of regional mammals. Results will have direct relevance for regional land management. The project will support a post-doctoral scientist and will engage university students and volunteers in field research, museum science, and scholarship. Results will support museum programs and K-12
science curricula on environmental change and the relevance of natural history collections to this important topic.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Over a period of four years, this award supported an ongoing project that uses information from historical and modern field surveys to measure recent changes in biological communities of the Great Basin. The rich biodiversity of this region is now in jeopardy due to accelerating climate change and human land-use history. Over the past 50 years, the Great Basin has experienced increased temperature and precipitation, declining winter snowpack, and earlier arrival of spring. Highly transformative land uses over the past 150 years have changed vegetation, reduced water availability, promoted invasive plants, and increased the frequency and severity of wild fires. These factors have greatly altered natural plant and animal communities in the Great Basin which is now considered one of the most threatened ecosystems in North America. This project focuses on small mammals (rodents and shrews) that are diverse and abundant in the Great Basin. Small mammals are excellent indicators of how natural systems vary over both space and time. Local communities include species with different habits and ecological requirements. Some are highly specialized with respect to their habitat affinities, diets, physical tolerances, and seasonal activity patterns, while others are generalists that can adapt to a wide variety of ecological situations. As a result, mammal communities differ dramatically, and predictably, between different habitats such as those found across elevation and they respond very rapidly to local environmental changes. Our project uses information from museum collections to create "snapshots" of the habitat structure and mammal communities present at precise localities at specific times in the past. Modern resurveys at these places provide comparative information allowing us to measure changes that have occurred across resurvey intervals of a few years to more than a century. Through resurveys on multiple mountains we have examined variation in the responses of species and communities to environmental change at different spatial scales. Some species have experienced up-slope shifts in their distributions consistent with predictions of climate warming, but others have remained static or exhibited downward shifts. It is clear that many of the reactions of mammals represent secondary responses to widespread changes in plant community structure rather than direct responses to climate change. Changes in mammal community structure that favor ecological generalists over specialists appear to be widespread. Other responses are more localized. Dramatic reductions in small mammal abundance, total biomass, and energy utilization were seen in the Ruby Mountains of Nevada suggesting a broad scale loss of productivity over an 80-year resurvey interval. In contrast, similar reductions were not apparent over the same time interval in the nearby Toiyabe Range. Our assessment of the recent effects of livestock grazing on plants and small mammals provides insight into how reduced grazing has shaped current communities independently of climate change; results that are relevant to both range management and conservation. Through collaborative research with paleontologists, we are expanding our temporal perspective on community dynamics by including information from the regional fossil record, thereby connecting research efforts in the fields of paleoecology and conservation biology. Project results have been reported in professional peer-reviewed publications (three published, three accepted and in press, others in various stages of preparation), and through presentations at scientific conferences.
